extendedIngredients.name: buttermilk
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3-4 T.buttermilk (or regular milk plus more if needed) — room temperature NOT cold
metaInformation: plus more if needed) — room temperature not

extendedIngredients.name: cocoa powder
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 cup unsweetened natural cocoa powder (not Dutch process)

extendedIngredients.name: coffee
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 cup freshly brewed coffee, cooled to room temperature

extendedIngredients.name: powdered sugar
extendedIngredients.originalString: 3 cups sifted powdered sugar (3 ½ cups unsifted)

extendedIngredients.name: salt
extendedIngredients.originalString: Pinch or two of salt — if using salted butter, omit

extendedIngredients.name: salted butter
extendedIngredients.originalString: 1 1/2 sticks (6 oz) unsalted or salted butter, room temperature (important)

extendedIngredients.name: unsalted butter
extendedIngredients.originalString: 2 sticks (8 ounces) unsalted butter, at room temperature

recipes.title: Chocolate Butter Cake

winePairing.pairingText: Cream Sherry, Port, and Moscato d'Asti are my top picks for Butter Cake. A common wine pairing rule is to make sure your wine is sweeter than your food. Delicate desserts go well with Moscato d'Asti, nutty desserts with cream sherry, and caramel or chocolate desserts pair well with port. The NV Johnson Estate Cream Sherry with a 5 out of 5 star rating seems like a good match. It costs about 19 dollars per bottle.

productMatches.title: NV Johnson Estate Cream Sherry
productMatches.description: Very aromatic with notes of hazelnut, vanilla, and a touch of oak followed by sweet raisins and a touch of yeast. Clean lasting finish. Good now but will reward those allow it to age"". A favorite pre-prandial beverage. Consider it with nuts before dinner as an aperitif, or after dinner with dessert, especially chocolates and fruit-based desserts. Also wonderful on cold afternoons, served with biscotti to dip in ""Italian-style"". "

recipes.instructions: Preheat the oven to 350F. Spray 2 8-inch round cake pans with flour-added cooking spray. Line bottoms with rounds of parchment paper.Combine the flour, sugar, cocoa, baking soda and salt in mixing bowl and stir very well to combine. Add the soft butter and buttermilk and blend on low (I used a stand mixer with a paddle) until smooth.Whisk the eggs, vanilla and cooled coffee together in another bowl and add to the batter in 3 additions, scraping down the sides of the bowl and mixing until blended. Try not to beat a lot of air into the egg mixture as you add it – just stir well. Scrape bottom of bowl and make sure to mix in all batter.Divide the batter among the pans and bake on center rack for 38 to 44 minutes or until a wooden toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean. Let cool in pans for about 5 minutes, the turn invert onto wire racks to cool completely. Remove parchment when cool.Chocolate Frosting: Melt both chocolates in microwave, double boiler or bowl set over barely simmering water; set aside to cool.Beat the butter until creamy. Make sure it’s not too cold or it might cause the chocolate to re-solidify. Stir in the cocoa power, about a cup of the powdered sugar, and the cooled melted chocolate. Scrape sides of bowl and beat well; add remaining powdered sugar, then add room temperature milk, vanilla and salt, beating and scraping until you get the consistency you like.

steps.step: Preheat the oven to 350F. Spray 2 8-inch round cake pans with flour-added cooking spray. Line bottoms with rounds of parchment paper.
Combine the flour, sugar, cocoa, baking soda and salt in mixing bowl and stir very well to combine.
Add the soft butter and buttermilk and blend on low (I used a stand mixer with a paddle) until smooth.

Whisk the eggs, vanilla and cooled coffee together in another bowl and add to the batter in 3 additions, scraping down the sides of the bowl and mixing until blended. Try not to beat a lot of air into the egg mixture as you add it – just stir well. Scrape bottom of bowl and make sure to mix in all batter.Divide the batter among the pans and bake on center rack for 38 to 44 minutes or until a wooden toothpick inserted in the center comes out clean.
Let cool in pans for about 5 minutes, the turn invert onto wire racks to cool completely.

Remove parchment when cool.Chocolate Frosting: Melt both chocolates in microwave, double boiler or bowl set over barely simmering water; set aside to cool.Beat the butter until creamy. Make sure it’s not too cold or it might cause the chocolate to re-solidify. Stir in the cocoa power, about a cup of the powdered sugar, and the cooled melted chocolate. Scrape sides of bowl and beat well; add remaining powdered sugar, then add room temperature milk, vanilla and salt, beating and scraping until you get the consistency you like.
